Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement,” while the second examines “displacement.” In the opening chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world prioritizes time as the organizing force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He contends that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this post.) Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then—nor am I now—a math person. I hate math. I am math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to answer the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I found a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited practical joker.

It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely incredible—I have nothing negative to say about this game as it's surpassed my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. Smooth movement, bug-free gameplay, plenty of story/content to keep you engaged, with daily options like multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even matches. This review focuses solely on MyCareer, and so far, it's a perfect 10/10. The facescan worked well for me (used it twice, though the first attempt gave me a comically large forehead). Remember, using the MyNBA2K17 app lets you facescan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience—a game meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, yet gold is essential. It's so vital that they've implemented a daily cap, understandable since gold unlocks everything in-game. But prepare for a tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even chat with. If you opt to play for free, expect to spend roughly 4 hours daily for over a month, alone, just to unlock the cards.

Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negatives first. I strongly dislike prequels since they technically move backward in a story rather than forward (a common issue for every prequel). Admittedly, it expands the narrative. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the precision Arkham City achieved. As of this review (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug prevents completing a side mission (main story unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to awkward hotkeys, forcing your hand to stretch across the entire keyboard. It might seem minor, but during combat, it can disrupt your flow.

They basically improved *Shadow Warrior* (2013). The boss fights are awesome, weapons feel great (maybe not as good as *DOOM*'s, but still solid), and enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not careless with handling elemental and upgrade mechanics). The upgrade system is well-balanced and, once you understand it, not too tedious. The elemental effects and limited ammo gently encourage you to switch between weapons. There are plenty of cool unique (key word here when comparing *SW2* to Borderlands' formula of RNG weapons) weapons that remain viable through most of the game. The music is fantastic, especially the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's tracks.

So many things were done wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and already has all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed I couldn't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game tell me that before I create a character, or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, etc). I felt much more connected to this character as well. The story starts out rough but improves significantly as you play (I think this is true for every AC game). Edward was a fascinating character, and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually mattered in this AC game, unlike previous ones, perhaps because they served a greater purpose. They definitely weren't required, but they were fun to collect and rewarded you in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn’t completely terrible. The gunplay is decent, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which is my primary complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is a great concept. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction system is off-putting for me. If you’re fine with this model, then by all means, enjoy. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just skip this one; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can lead to frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of 20. Would have really appreciated a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is too small and the zoom is underwhelming. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not usually a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up gameplay is fantastic. I've been playing it whenever possible... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm fleeing and need to reach safety before quitting.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I must say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. I’m not sure exactly how many there are, but there's a ton! The graphics are stunning, the sounds are fantastic, and the gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box on the main menu is very entertaining too—no, I’m not kidding. However, if you think this game is 'easy,' or if you’re new to the strategy genre, it might take some time to master. Don’t get frustrated; you’ll lose many units. Just plan ahead, always bring anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was negatively biased towards this game before I played it. I wasn’t even sure about buying it. I dunno, the whole portal gun and portals concept seemed weird to me, even though I like science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal—just amazing. It's not cheesy (okay, sometimes it's cheesy). And each story character has their own sense of humor. Those different characters genuinely have distinct personalities. And the level design? It's just rad. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I’m planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn’t tried the sequel.

Ok, let's discuss the pros(+) and cons(-) along with my thoughts on this game.  
+Some of the best characters  
+Good story  
+Lots of content  
+Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you prefer)  
+You can have relationships with most companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest)  
-Bad graphics (though I don’t think graphics really matter)  
-Weird and awkward love scenes  
-Invisible walls  
-There’s one mission I found boring, but everyone has different tastes  
+/- This isn’t really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can’t talk.  

Now for my thoughts: I love this game. It’s probably one of the best RPGs—or games in general—I’ve ever played. So if you’re an RPG fan, you likely already own it.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others return, instantly recognizable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cel-shaded style is flawless and quintessentially Generation One. Beyond nostalgia, it's genuinely an enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally polished. Transforming mid-fight is often essential, seamlessly integrated into combos, setting it apart from High Moon's outstanding *War for/Fall of Cybertron* games. Another standout feature is the emphasis on melee combat, though some foes (e.g., Seekers) demand switching to ranged weapons.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it claims there was an update to the terms of service, and clicking 'accept' just makes it reappear. You have to restart the client for it to work. That's not too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and GFace accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that necessary? It's also irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam info. As for the game itself, it's mediocre. It's clearly a COD clone, yet somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo An excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just keep in mind there's lots of (skippable) dialogue. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally, I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup—both fully rebindable. The price is fair, and I wouldn't regret the purchase. Over half the DLC is included free, offering plenty to enjoy. Highly recommended for JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, as long as you don't mind slower pacing. Cheers. No-commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches it runs really well. Imo, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you control Batman + one more character), and the option to use a controller for most of the game but switch to mouse and keyboard for tank combat was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the open city, especially during APC chases, is quite enjoyable once you learn to use the brakes for skidding around corners (and when you master that, cruising through the city becomes incredibly fun!).

Damn fine AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great—excellent FPS mechanics, a compelling story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted though—some cutscenes are brutally vivid. But when a game is this outstanding, flaws stand out more, and here's what I noticed:  
- No SLI support—seriously? I had to shelve it until upgrading my card since it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a solid single-GPU setup.  
- Ridiculously small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch. So please excuse any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories:  
- Graphics  
- Controls  
- Sound  
- Gameplay  
- Replayability  

Graphics: The game features a comic-like style. The visuals are very sleek, with no unnecessary details. The color schemes are pleasing and perfectly suit the game. You can set the graphics to 'high' without straining your system. I run this game on an i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB RAM, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1).  

Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I’ve put into this game that I truly enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don’t buy this game thinking it’s like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter. It’s in a class of its own and should be treated as such. Can’t tell you how many times I hear new players whine and complain about dying too quickly. Oh, heaven forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It’s not like that doesn’t happen in real life or anything. Edit: Okay, so I’ve been playing this game for a while now. Invested a lot of money into it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A great choice when you’re not feeling CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and absolutely loving this game. So funny. Gameplay is solid, the art design is stunning, music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story/world has me hooked, and the puzzles are enjoyable. But the best part beyond all that is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to RPGs, you'll still adore the humor. If you played *Final Fantasy VII* or *X*, you absolutely need to try this—without spoiling anything... I had to pause after two hours just to rest my cheeks from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded perfect for me, but the execution fell flat. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this one completely unintuitive. Even after checking how to progress, I simply didn't enjoy the gameplay. It also lacks a pause button—or if it exists, I never found it. Given that many sequences are timed, this seems like a major oversight. Additionally, the game feels more like a series of cutscenes than actual gameplay, leaving me waiting impatiently most of the time.

This game... Phew, where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful, from the story to the graphics—I was hooked. The story wasn’t just some tale but actually made me feel like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the journey my character was telling. The gameplay was great, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or sequel, I’d be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this—you created a truly beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory'. In previous games, you progressed through Earth's timeline, advancing from the Stone Age to the Medieval and Modern eras; however, this game is set in the future as you colonize a new planet. What I enjoy is how 2K introduced fresh mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. What I didn’t like was that these additions could sometimes feel overwhelming. One improvement I’d suggest is incorporating new artwork, such as the environment seen when interacting with other leaders.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's designed like a survival horror where you must conserve ammo, treat your wounds when bleeding, take pills when infected, etc. Also, the zombies feel very natural and are well animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I’d recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly, and you can easily make friends or chat with others via text or voice.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't fully recommend this game because, from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if not for these two major issues. No Aussie servers—a single red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and causes unbearable lag. Keep in mind, even the offline training mode stuttered and lagged (how does that happen?). Combine that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the experience. Everything artifacts excessively—the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this issue before with this card and wondered if it disliked my overclock. I reset my GPU to stock settings, but it made no difference.

Very late last night I finished this. The story isn't particularly deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is brimming with detail, and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I learned a lot about Batman's world, so it was disappointing that so few bosses were included. Oh well, future games can rectify that. The combat offers the right amount of challenge but leans toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that introduce fresh gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas creates a rewarding sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's *The Walking Dead* is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for *To the Moon*! Never before have I been so moved yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so compelling that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is delightful as well, and it never intrudes upon the poignant nature of the story... And the *Doctor Who* references are endless.

Bastion is an absolutely brilliant game, with a captivating storyline. Set after a calamity, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. There's a wealth of choice in the game, from deciding what to build for an advantage, which weapons to wield, and what upgrades to apply, as well as selecting drinks for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that prove the apocalypse doesn’t have to be dull. Best of all, the game features dynamic narration based on your actions. For instance, if you pick up a weapon and then swap it in the armoury, the narration comments on your choice of the new weapon.

I originally purchased this game during early development, when the only currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was great. All guns were equally overpowered, so imbalance wasn't an issue; anyone could defeat anyone at any time. Additionally, the game provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You'd think a game boasting 'bajillions of guns' would offer more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring payment for extras. At one point, I owned about 3 pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more—that's where I found the fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews for certain products that can be misleading. In this case, the reviews truly reflect the fun of this neat little game. It’s an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn’t typically like in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue but decided to try a melee tank anyway. I was pleasantly surprised by the outcome and ended up experimenting more as they unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from crafting a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every battle, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counterattack. Thanks, devs, for an amazing experience!

The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original games may be disappointed by the alterations to their beloved character, these shifts are ultimately for the better—and this new title by Ninja Theory proves it. *DmC* serves as the ideal entry point for newcomers to the series. It explores the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicles his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game crafts a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story traces his journey as he confronts the corrupt world he once willfully ignored.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with so much detail, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It knows when to be serious but isn't afraid of funny moments. The character design is flawless, featuring diverse personalities and hidden depths. It stands out from other RPGs because you don’t have to kill anyone—a rare concept in the genre. Drawing heavy inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I’ve seen, it’s clear this game is special. Plus, it boasts the best soundtrack I’ve heard in years.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way. Maybe I'm desensitized, or perhaps it was too simplistic to provoke a reaction. The other half attempts to portray (literally) a person's mental decline. It explores obsession, hallucination, depression, and other themes. In theory, it's an intriguing concept. However, the 'game' took me just 10 minutes to complete, even while carefully reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps back. It's a brilliant way to challenge your mind while remaining fun. Although this game isn't story-heavy, it spawned one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play and complete it when bored, and I love returning to see what birthed a legend and what became one. Gameplay: Portal's mechanics are simple to explain. You use portals strategically, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two button types: one you press and one requiring a cube.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both issues are resolved—one fix boosted my fps from 60-90 to 80-120—and are seeking a space exploration game, I highly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX 480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). At ~650€, this setup falls squarely in the mid-range, though admittedly, it's fairly new. Nearly constant 60+ fps on high settings with V-Sync enabled—I’m baffled by 90% of comments claiming they have overkill rigs yet get 20fps.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since we've seen an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to being my personal favorite. Combine this with a massive Risk-like grand strategy mode, and it truly hits the mark. I try not to be overly biased, but this game lets you transform into a dragon, supporting your troops by attacking, aiding, and even directing unit production and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do enjoy complex RTS games nowadays, like Civ V and others. However, such games often cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single overwhelming experience.

Undertale combines its elements to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is pleasant, but together they craft truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script spans from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, while subverting RPG tropes. And all this without even mentioning the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are highly active in the community, evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still mastering; however, this depth of strategy offers countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. The game, in my opinion, is nearly infinitely replayable. I find myself engrossed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those enjoyable initial hours, you'll notice that the only thing left is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The standout feature is the developers' dedication, with semi-frequent updates that often introduce substantial content—from sweeping system changes to new warframes and additional tweaks. It's a great game to play casually. However, it may not hold your attention beyond a few months unless you truly enjoy grinding. The best part is that the game is free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for a quick fix, it's worth checking out.

This game is so... very... boring. I bought it because I believed it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you go around absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and collect more. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack creativity, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining one, but rather one that leaves you depressed and questioning the meaning of existence. Every "living" creature in this game, from small pets to humans, makes me wonder if the developers had a fascination with taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, *Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!* Well, it really wasn't. The game starts by making you pick a side: Republican or Democrat—there's no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I’ll give the game credit: the character customization, though limited, is pretty fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you get the option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was better. Settlements interfere with the narrative to the point where you'll resent managing them instead of enjoying the story. Some keys are hard coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs are rampant. My pipboy vanished permanently at one point, forcing me to research console commands to restore it. Power armor requires no effort—it's handed to you early in the game, and fusion cores are abundant in shops. The value of power armor is greatly diminished compared to previous Fallout titles. The story is mediocre, and most aspects of this game are average, though it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It's far more stable than Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was massively overhyped for how disappointing it truly is.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the song by Steve Miller Band...: 'Go on, take the money and run uh uh uhhh! Go on, take the money and run!' https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. OMFG, just an hour in this game! It's awesome! Some guns are OP, and matchmaking is sometimes unfair, but hey, BF3 has worse matchmaking. A newbie and higher-level players weren't real humans—you shot them in the face and nothing happened!

It's not hard for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I own a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scope of its universe, but I also felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting early on were both too much for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more free time, this would appeal to me. But I lack both, and there are plenty of other VR games I'd rather play.

Hands down my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always prove fatal unless they merely graze you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are essential to stay on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you constantly reload mid-magazine, you’ll end up with a pouch full of half-empty mags. You can't sprint indefinitely. If you run too long, your aim will falter as you gasp for air until you recover. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window ledge to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out and that I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved it, however—it was unforgiving early on but rewarding when you succeeded. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game runs well for me on medium settings with a GTX 560 and 2GB of VRAM. Initially, it defaulted to high and ran sluggishly, though not unplayably so, but switching to medium smoothed things out. I’m not sure if I’m just lucky with game issues, but many negative reviews sound like they come from overly entitled people.

+RPG leveling +Wide variety of ship types +Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles +Easy-to-learn resource management +Dark humor -Grind-heavy (if underutilizing civilian stations) -Subpar AI teammates -Limited equipment variety -Few leveling skill options (no branching) Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite the drawbacks above, there's still plenty of variety and strategy. It starts fast and only gets better. Even with limited equipment, there's always another ship to unlock or skill to upgrade. The best way to extend the game's lifespan is through mods. Fight for Universe is easily the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also excellent.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political figures from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalization campaigners have canceled a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to coincide with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a dispute over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, after Monday's 4% rise on hopes of a payout. The US firm is believed to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticised the Iraq War, stating that billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. In his Christmas message, he denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have voiced opposition to the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that "billions" were spent on war instead of lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The Cardinal declared that 2005 should be the year to campaign and "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed, with actors and directors missing out on prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* failed to secure the director or screenplay awards, and star Imelda Staunton also went unrecognized. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo missed out on Best Supporting honors. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama *Wasp*. Arnold, who hosted children's shows *Number 73* and *Motormouth* in the 1980s, called the win "totally overwhelming." *Wasp* follows a struggling single mother, triumphing over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the '70s horror classic *Halloween*, has died in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60 million (£31.3m) worldwide—a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the '70s that were typically held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression, as fast web access encourages more people to share their thoughts online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It revealed that always-on, high-speed connections are transforming how people use the internet. Over five million UK households now have broadband, and adoption rates are rising rapidly. The Demos report examined broadband's influence on online behavior. It found that more than half of broadband users log on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking up at night to browse. Most notably, the report argues that broadband motivates people to engage more actively online.

Yukos heads back to US courts as the Russian oil and gas company continues its fight for survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, aiming to use international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now argue the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any buyer of its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting begins for the annual Bloggies, which honor the best web blogs—online spaces where people share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily shut down due to overwhelming visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from top regional blog to best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a leading US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks roughly six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think tank Pew Internet and American Life, yet fewer than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to Chinese state media. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam persists in work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, reported *The Beijing News*. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects suspended due to insufficient environmental reviews. *The Beijing News* noted the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other sites—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown directive.

Man City 0-2 Man Utd: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unlucky Dunne volleyed over David James' head into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from close range in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to secure the win they needed to stay in the title race. Their build-up play was more sluggish than patient, and they created just one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' as the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained the "essentials" were in place. Both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, argued Dr Gibbons needed to revise policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, stating waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff desired a period of stability after "tremendous change and reform." One of the major issues Ms Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve  
Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' resilient performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season, and it was a thrilling match, end-to-end with excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed great character and determination, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also lauded senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought composure to the midfield, which we needed and no other player could provide.

Singer's film to screen at festival  
A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will be featured in the Panorama section of the festival, running from 10–20 February. It showcases the singer reflecting on his career and personal journey, from his Wham! days to recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film highlights Michael discussing his early years in Wham!, his later career, legal disputes with record label Sony, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart: Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart incorporates data from music download sales, previously limited to a separate chart. Green Day's *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* is currently number two on Billboard's Pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales will be added to the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the updated Hot 100 chart. A second new chart—the Pop 100—also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard as the net's self-declared spam king seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, claims lawsuits forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was fighting multiple legal battles, notably against Microsoft, which seeks millions in damages. The company stated filing for Chapter 11 would help resolve its legal issues while continuing operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. The lawsuit, filed by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleged Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses across 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has dismissed claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one reason he resigned, and that is his personal issues. He has spoken to me recently and said this matter is entirely his own." Arnesen said he could not shed any light on the problems that led Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never specified what it was. But I trust him on that; you must accept it. I believe we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and another penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away wins, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will aim to give coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Economic focus for election battle: Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has said. He spoke after cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 before the expected election announcement. He stated voters would recognize that Labour had delivered stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined plans to tackle 'yob culture,' and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting public fears. In an open letter, he called on them to avoid turning the election into a contest about who can most effectively scare voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run AAA's in Sheffield. Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy aims to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit recently. He is one of the fastest 800m runners globally this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked third in the world 3000m rankings, with Cragg holding the top spot.

Robinson aims for dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has set his sights on victories over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a huge achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England have the opportunity to secure their third autumn international win after consecutive victories over Canada and South Africa, while also avenging June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of disappointment against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website that claims to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible because it mimics an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, DEC has no connection with the fake site and states it has reported the matter to police. The site is just the latest in a series of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email currently circulating. The message's subject line reads 'Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal' and its text contains the poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids  
Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly expand nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids will be accepted from local, Arab, and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications announced. The winner will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and manage a fixed-line network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry stated its goal to raise Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to roughly 25% within 10 years." It also aims to establish a "highly visible and adaptable telecommunication sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. A roadshow for investors is also planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women and older people are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for cybersecurity firm Preventon, reveals that security awareness is reaching a diverse range of internet users. Approximately 40% of those buying home security software are retirees. Over the past three years, this figure has increased by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) invested in security programs than retired men. The research highlights shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, along with growing recognition of the heightened risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a significant amount of space to fill. But increasingly, iPod owners are using that space for audio content produced by a diverse range of creators. This is called 'podcasting,' and its biggest advocate is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting derives its name from the Apple iPod, though you don’t need an iPod to make or listen to one. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, typically created by podcasters from their homes. All they require is a microphone, a computer, and basic editing software. They then upload their shows online, allowing others to download and listen for free.

Levy wins Whitbread novel prize  
Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book *Small Island*. She is now the frontrunner to win the overall prize after defeating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean secured the children's fiction award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*. All category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A judging panel featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to select the overall winner, with the announcement made that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has listed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm that purchased its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the $20bn sale of Yuganskneftegas for damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a US court order last week halting the sale. Baikal's background and motives for the acquisition remain unclear. Russian newspapers allege that Baikal—which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) at a state-backed auction on Sunday—has close ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, scoring twice within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller struck inside the opening minute, heading Jamie McAllister's free-kick over Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister then added the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to extend their lead. Craig Easton pulled one back with a contentious header after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out. McAllister delivered the free-kick into the box, where Miller outjumped the static defense to loop his header over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes in, the hosts doubled their advantage as Mikoliunas sprinted down the right and crossed for McAllister to head home.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service that enables customers needing massive computing power to rent it hourly. Sun Grid charges users $1 (53p) for an hour of processing and storage on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest trend in an industry where computing capacity is as vital as hardware and software. Sun compared grid computing to the evolution of electricity. The system could grow similarly to utilities like electricity and water, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz. 'Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?' he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots  
Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she aims to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches remains a key priority. Ms Jamieson spoke ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long tied to sections of both clubs' support has become a major focus for the Executive. Last week, Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie: Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film *Beyond the Sea* in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, performs all 18 songs on the soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have signed Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley was approved after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed-line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that increasingly more people rely on their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobiles. It found that individuals retain fixed-line phones due to lower call charges, but most respondents agreed the future is undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research indicated that mobiles and landlines serve distinct purposes. Home phones were preferred for longer calls, while mobile conversations tended to be shorter, often with friends. In the UK, 69% of participants said they still use their landline because it remains cheaper than a mobile.

Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was repeatedly bamboozled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a solid game plan and executed it perfectly," he said. "It's always tough to face Andre. I didn't want him to dictate play. He makes you run relentlessly across the court.

MPs tout Lords replacement plan: A group of MPs has sought to increase pressure on Tony Blair over House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group claims it can secure support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government delayed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, citing insufficient support due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued that consensus on reforms is necessary. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals to alter at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott in solid start Allan Scott remains confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a strong debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. 'It was certainly a learning curve, and I haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week,' said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg took second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his final performance. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge falsely signals the printer to refill even when unnecessary. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has bought an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment on the case. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt users to replace them. However, the lawsuit alleges the chips also deactivate the cartridges prematurely, regardless of remaining ink.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio announces it will become the first station globally to deliver radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, collaborating with technology firm Sydus, will transmit on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from Virgin's website to access the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, stated: "It places radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will debut first, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland added: "This application allows anyone, anywhere to enjoy Virgin Radio with just their phone.

Roxy Music is set to appear at June's Isle of Wight music festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, running from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the festival's Saturday night. The band is also working on new material in the studio, their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*, followed by classics like *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the aid match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bulloch, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern squad. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. The game offers Woodward a chance to evaluate some options before announcing his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

Spirit Awards hail *Sideways* The comedy *Sideways* dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six categories for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also earned acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for *Maria Full of Grace*.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' of 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual list. The singer earned $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties through his *Musicology* tour and album. He outpaced Madonna, who secured second place with $54.9 million (£29.5 million) during her global *Re-Invention* tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel ranked 10th, earning $24.9 million (£13.4 million) from their comeback tour. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine noted. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, *Musicology*.

Irish band U2 have been honoured at France's biggest music awards but were beaten to a prize by boy band Blue. U2 received a special achievement award at the NRJ Music Awards, while Blue claimed the international group title. US band Maroon 5 won best new international artist and earned the best international song award for *This Love*. Over five million radio listeners voted in the ceremony. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne, respectively. Accepting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell in Cannes, U2 frontman Bono said in French: *"I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession—it's on the Côte d'Azur I feel at home."*

The Tories outlined policing plans under which local communities would be asked to elect their own area police commissioner, as proposed by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He clarified that the new office would not override the role of a chief constable. The Lib Dems warned the plan could enable extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory promises on the issue. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, representing rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence. Jan Berry remarked: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every election cycle. These plans could allow those with extreme political views to dictate operations on the ground," she cautioned.

At a glance: The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the proposal: Individuals coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or longer and are from a country with high TB rates, they would require a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more must undergo a full medical examination. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa rejection. All other conditions would be assessed case by case.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes. Has there ever been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans worldwide after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two grand slam-winning sides in the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, called it "one of the most surreal games I’ve ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and a Welsh half."

Doves soar to UK album summit as Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replace flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows their single *Black and White Town*, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, *(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame*, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop artist Akon's *Locked Up* is at number five, while highly-rated Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs score their second chart hit at number six with *Oh My God*.

Davies favours Gloucester future Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to remain where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies without a club and forced him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before joining Gloucester that he was frustrated with his treatment.

Cabinet anger at Brown cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he stressed that local governments must maintain quality services without significant tax increases. The central government funding is part of a £1bn package to help English local authorities limit next year's council tax rises below 5%, ahead of a likely general election year. Mr Raynsford noted nearly all central government departments have a stake in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa as four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are set to play for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab side to compete in European competition, will face English Premier League club Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club, which won the Israeli Cup last season, is based in Sakhnin near Haifa. Known for their strong values, they actively promote peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll'—more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives annually. The findings are published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, states that reducing the limit would also prevent 230 serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003. He estimates this would save the country £119m yearly. A prior estimate, from a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a change could save 50 lives annually.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design offers a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time required for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and bulky analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital supply. The functionality of the system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam environment.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme designed to incentivize AVs to adopt centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by reducing toll costs, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level consists of a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model accounting for a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond coaxing ever larger objects into quantum behavior, this capability has inspired applications in quantum information processing, communication, and precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to broader quantum states, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested overcoming this limitation through strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have not yet achieved nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer product evaluations to help customers make decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have developed increasingly deceptive and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they may vary rapidly over time, differ across spammers and target products, and, more critically, remain unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which does not fully align with maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete based on practical goals beyond mere detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game yield stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control the transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We define a measure of robustness for uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which the infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses surpasses that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share a common structural form, partially identifying the true component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply when the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and remain valid even if the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we derive sharper results based on the scaling with the separation between the components.

We examine the relationship between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( x_m \) in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) within it by a dual group \( g^t \). In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is obtained as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple proof of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of human gait analysis was developed based on existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration movement during locomotion, aiming to reproduce walk-run transition behavior. The experimental results, obtained across various speed regimes, demonstrate that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center is a significant parameter for quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the biomedical engineering research group, basic sciences department, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method employs time regularization to preserve the stability of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. Using a high-order MVS scheme, we integrate with large time steps far from close encounters. This algorithm resolves near-collisions (within a fraction of a physical radius) while maintaining the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We demonstrate long-term stability on six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering over 50 kyr. Compared to hybrid methods like Mercury, our algorithm achieves superior energy conservation at equivalent computational cost.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator yields positive results for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can violate the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a far richer multipolar structure, offering a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only weak constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the LISA mission will enhance these bounds significantly.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging problem in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We examine a common scenario where edges can represent short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are frequently defined by humans. Human-specified edges can be both costly to create and ineffective for the downstream task. To address these limitations, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by analyzing node communication.
